trial_identification.studytitle: Protocol initiated discharge in a 23-hour post surgical ward: a randomized controlled trial.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Among patients admitted to a 23-hour post surgical unit, will using a protocol for discharge affect the number of discharges by 0900 hours and patient satisfaction.

interventions.interventions: Protocol having clear criteria for admission to the unit; the completion of surgery summaries and discharge prescriptions at the end of the procedure; and using the Modified Post Anaesthetic Discharge Scoring System (MPADSS) to assess if the patient is ready for discharge. The intervention covers the time from admission to the 23-hour unit to the time of discharge from the unit.
interventions.comparator: Usual care. No discharge protocol used. Patients are assessed as fit for discharge by their surgeon.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Proportion of patients discharged by 0900 hours. Assessed by time recorded in the patient's medical record.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Patient satisfaction is assessed by self-report questionnaire, which asks the patients to decribe positive aspects of the unit, negative aspects of the unit and suggestions for improvement. Participants are also asked to provide a score out of 100 for their care.
Hospital admission assesed using the patient's medical record.
Hospital re-admission assessed by asking the patient in a follow-up questionnaire or phone call.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Patients booked for surgery who were expected to be admitted to the 23-hour unit.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: No consent < 18 years Surgeon has not agreed to for patients to be included patients undergoing eye surgery

trial_design.concealment: Consenting patients were allocated by telephone randomisation.
trial_design.sequence: Sequence was generated by computer. Randomisation was blocked and patients were randomised 1:1 to a ‘normal care discharge’ group or a ‘protocol initiated discharge’ group

ethicsAndSummary.summary: There is limited published literature about the effectiveness of protocol initiated discharge in short-stay post-surgical units. The current study enrolled 182 participants who were randomly allocated to intervention or control groups.
ethicsAndSummary.publication: Webster J, Connolly A, Paton F, Corry J. The effectiveness of protocol driven, nurse-initiated discharge in a 23-h post surgical ward: A randomized controlled trial. International Journal of Nursing Studies 2011; 48:1173-1179
